Welcome to the seamonsters library documentation!¶

This is Team 2605’s Python library for robot code. It builds on wpilib and adds useful utilities for working with input, motors, drivetrains, and Commands, as well as for simulation without a robot and for quick and simple tests.

Terminology¶

In the documentation you will see the terms “position mode”, “incremental position mode”, and “jeff mode” used interchangeably. “Voltage mode” is used to refer either to Voltage or PercentVbus mode on CANTalons. Also, some classes use “velocity” in method/variable names while others use “speed.”

Rebuilding the documentation¶

This documentation was created with Sphinx. To update it, navigate to seamonsters/docs and run make html.

seamonsters.GeneratorBot()

seamonsters.IterativeRobotInstance(robotType) Allows an “instance” of an IterativeRobot to be created without connecting to HAL or LiveWindow.

seamonsters.LogState(name[, logFrequency]) Represents a value important to the user that is constantly changing.
seamonsters.MotorManager() A motor manager manages many CANTalons, with associated MultiMode’s.
seamonsters.MotorSpeedControl An abstract interface for controlling the speed of a motor.
seamonsters.MultiMode(talon, speedControl) An implementation of MotorSpeedControl that wraps another MotorSpeedControl implementation.
seamonsters.SpeedMode(talon) A CANTalon in speed mode.
seamonsters.SwerveDrive() An implementation of DriveInterface for swerve drives.
seamonsters.TalonWheelController(...) A wheel controller controlling two CANTalons.

seamonsters.VoltageMode(talon) A CANTalon in voltage mode (actually PercentVbus).
seamonsters.WheelController An interface for controlling a single swerve drive wheel
seamonsters.WheelState(location, controller) Keeps track of the current state of a single wheels, calculates all the necessary, vector math, and controls a WheelController.

seamonsters.wait(time) Wait for a certain number of iterations.
seamonsters.watch(\*iterables) Run a group of iterables in parallel.
